subject: [ADAMS] Urban Design Study
text:
Sending along for a friend.

My name is Sean Hayes (Harvard col. ’22).

As a part of my master’s dissertation on Urban Design at Cambridge
University I’m collecting data on the pedestrian experience in Harvard
Square. This data will be used to inform a strategy to pedestrianize
Harvard Square’s streets.

I’ve put together this brief survey (takes no longer than 2’ to complete)
and would be incredibly grateful for your input. Your opinions are crucial
to this plan becoming a reality!

https://forms.gle/FEK8NzTD7hsUuVRX7

Thank you for your time and help!

Sincerely,

Sean

scwh2@cam.ac.uk

subject: [ADAMS] Clinical Research Coordinator Position for Graduating Seniors
text:
*GENERAL SUMMARY/ OVERVIEW STATEMENT: * Dr. Anne-Marie Wills is looking to
hire a full time research coordinator to work on two-four clinical trials
for Parkinson’s disease.   The ideal candidate would be planning on a
future medical or allied health degree, and would be interested in working
in clinical research to gain experience and publications prior to going to
medical school.  A two-year commitment is required.  The coordinator must
be motivated, organized, and efficient, able to organize schedules,
evaluate participants, enter data electronically and respond quickly to
emails.  Prior clinical research experience is a plus but not required.



* PRINCIPAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:* •       Coordinate and schedule
clinical trial visits both in-person and remotely
•       Create online advertising, webinars, and video instruction materials
•       Maintain documentation for the Institutional Review Board.
•       Perform primary data collection at study visits, including
questionnaires and limited physiological monitoring.
•       Enter all study data into the electronic data capture system.
•       Monitor and reports adverse events as required by
Institutional/federal regulations

* SKILLS & COMPETENCIES REQUIRED: *

Candidate must have strong organizational skills, a willingness and ability
to learn, and interest in working with human research participants.  Good
interpersonal skills, attention to detail, the ability to prioritize
multiple tasks and handle fluctuating priorities and deadlines, good
communication skills, and the ability to work independently as well as with
others are required.  Prior clinical research experience is a plus but not
required.





*EDUCATION: * Minimum Required:
Bachelor’s Degree


Contact Dr. Anne-Marie Wills at awills@mgh.harvard.edu if interested.

“I read the daily poems from The Slowdown with my morning coffee. These poems are a gift.” - Richarda E. 





Contemporary art and poetry encourage uncertainty and a spirit of inquiry. If we are willing to let go of our frustration, abandoning the quest for meaning can be its own spiritual reward. Today’s extraordinary poem constructs a fascinating and dreamy space where images sharpen into an immense and profound notion of the land and human interdependence.        

  
— Major

The Half-Finished Heaven
 by Tomas Tranströmer



Cowardice breaks off on its path.


Anguish breaks off on its path.


The vulture breaks off in its flight.
 

The eager lights runs into the open,


Even the ghosts take a drink.
 

And our paintings see the air,


red beasts of the ice-age studios.
 

Everything starts to look around.


We go out in the sun by hundreds.
 

Every person is a half-open door


leading to a room for everyone.
 

The endless field under us.


Water glitters between the trees.

 


The lake is a window into the earth.

subject: My new TED Talk: see how we’re using AI to revolutionize learning
text:
Khan Academy





 
 

https://click.e.khanacademy.org/?qs=17487ad1fec8cd418e3489817899d07df3297b4f477cd108c33169fddca7c4e5a41d58105ff9654a23a8efb263ee63e178d700b9472e902ef0440c16f822b9a1 



https://click.e.khanacademy.org/?qs=17487ad1fec8cd41c0ef66063f8ace5bf4cc7e93d235f9a11078f03dca0c32291bfc52acfc0baa1eea9159a25099780a6c50aa2e1ed9c9cf36c04070fb349096 


 

Dear ,

I want to invite you to watch my new TED Talk, "Using AI to Reinvent Education". In this talk, I discuss the exciting potential of AI in education, and how Khan Academy plans to harness this technology to enhance human potential, intelligence, and purpose.


https://click.e.khanacademy.org/?qs=17487ad1fec8cd41c0ef66063f8ace5bf4cc7e93d235f9a11078f03dca0c32291bfc52acfc0baa1eea9159a25099780a6c50aa2e1ed9c9cf36c04070fb349096 
Watch my TED talk 


As many of you may know, there has been a lot of concern in the education community about the uncertain impact of AI on learning. However, I firmly believe that if we put the right guardrails and take the right approach, we can mitigate these concerns and use AI to drive the biggest positive transformation that education has ever seen. Khan Academy is here to lead the charge as a voice trusted by millions of learners. 


 
With our new AI tutor, Khanmigo, we can give every student an artificially intelligent personal tutor, and every teacher an amazing teaching assistant. This is not a tool for getting answers-- it is a tool for personalized learning, guidance, and support unlike we've ever seen possible.
 



I demonstrated some of the features of Khanmigo in my talk, such as its ability to ask Socratic questions, detect misconceptions, and act as a world-class writing tutor. But this is just the beginning. We believe that Khanmigo can be a game-changer for education, and we are working hard to make it even better with your help. You can access Khanmigo now after making a donation to Khan Academy.
 
 
 


https://click.e.khanacademy.org/?qs=17487ad1fec8cd4129c25e93ca4d881c1d4cf6f4bf55ba562788414ca1e5b2fc96abbb8ae89f50e148eff64afa1eaba799752ed6a5bd38ed8c91ee4c2111a52c 
Sign up for Khanmigo 


As I said in my talk, we're at the cusp of using AI for probably the biggest positive transformation that education has ever seen. But we need your help to make this happen. We need to fight for the positive uses of AI, and it will start with students like you who use it to reach your amazing potential. I hope you will watch my talk and ask your parents about signing up for Khanmigo to join us in this mission to uplift humanity through AI and education.


Best,

Sal Khan

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/01/13/reader-center/author-german-lopez/author-german-lopez-blogSmallThumb-v2.png]https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jPchzf4jq3afXtLqoVLefA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmM2ntP0S8aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA1MDImaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE1NTUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTg3OCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD_t5FBkAHB7MVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~

By German Lopez
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jPchzf4jq3afXtLqoVLefA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmM2ntP0S8aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vYnkvZ2VybWFuLWxvcGV6P2NhbXBhaWduX2lkPTkmZW1jPWVkaXRfbm5fMjAyMzA1MDImaW5zdGFuY2VfaWQ9OTE1NTUmbmw9dGhlLW1vcm5pbmcmcmVnaV9pZD05ODEwOTE2OCZzZWdtZW50X2lkPTEzMTg3OCZ0ZT0xJnVzZXJfaWQ9YmEyZmY2OWVkNmU5ZmVjNmYzMWYzMjJjZTUzNGJkMTVXA255dEIKZD_t5FBkAHB7MVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]

Good morning. The bank crisis could hurt the whole economy.



[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/05/02/multimedia/02themorning-lead-vgjl/02themorning-lead-vgjl-jumbo.jpg]Regulators
seized control of First Republic Bank and sold it to JPMorgan Chase
yesterday.Ian C. Bates for The New York Times


BANK RUNS

The recent fall of major banks — including First Republic Bank yesterday — has
caused concerns that the U.S. is on the brink of a financial catastrophe, one
that could resemble the 2007-8 crisis that led to the Great Recession.

Three times this year, fearful bank customers and investors have rushed to
withdraw their money, and the federal government has taken drastic action to
prevent a broader panic that could knock down the rest of the financial system.
Nobody knows for certain whether this third time will be the last.

For now, the situation has stabilized. The stock market held steady yesterday,
and other banks seemed to be doing fine
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/YwYn-bv0c9_7sL9JHJGq7w~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmM2ntP0TraHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNS8wMS9idXNpbmVzcy9maXJzdC1yZXB1YmxpY3MtcmVnaW9uYWwtYmFua3MtY3Jpc2lzLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTU1NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxODc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP-3kUGQAcHsxUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].

But a crisis has not necessarily been averted. History is filled with examples
of leaders who believed they had stopped a disaster but later found they had
underestimated the problem, including during the 2007-8 financial collapse. Some
analysts worry that other banks may have as-yet undiscovered problems. And the
Federal Reserve, America’s central bank, is likely to continue to raise interest
rates — the very thing that catalyzed this year’s bank collapses.

So why does this matter to everyday Americans? A financial crisis can lead to
less spending across the entire economy, suppressing jobs and wages. It can also
hurt people’s investments, including retirement accounts and other savings.

Today’s newsletter will look at the bank collapses and their potential
consequences to the broader economy.


LOST FAITH

Regulators seized First Republic Bank and sold it to the financial behemoth
JPMorgan Chase
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/Cv_Mp2OYuLyxgMjUcp-SqA~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmM2ntP0TiaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNS8wMS9idXNpbmVzcy9maXJzdC1yZXB1YmxpYy1iYW5rLWpwbW9yZ2FuLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTU1NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxODc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP-3kUGQAcHsxUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA]
yesterday. This deal — in which a bigger bank absorbs a struggling one — is
typical during a crisis. What is less typical is the magnitude of this year’s
failures. Combined, First Republic, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank held
more in inflation-adjusted assets
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/W4xCayzGi9ZrumOw38CcfQ~~/AAAAAQA~_7eRQZABwezFSH2VlbGFhZnphaGlkQGNvbGxlZ2UuaGFydmFyZC5lZHVYBAAAAAA~]
than the 25 U.S. banks that collapsed in 2008.

[https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/05/01/briefing/oakImage-1682971255220/oakImage-1682971255220-jumbo.png]Source:
Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation | Data is adjusted for inflation. | By
Karl Russell

The three banks, and their falls, had some important traits in common.

First, the banks’ investments were particularly exposed to the risk of rising
interest rates. As the Federal Reserve increased interest rates over the past
year, many of First Republic’s assets lost value because they were fixed at
lower interest rates and, therefore, lower payouts to the bank. Meanwhile, First
Republic had to pay now-higher interest rates on its customers’ deposits. The
mix of lower revenue and higher costs toppled the bank’s balance sheet.

Second, the three banks had a large share of customers with deposits that
surpassed federal insurance limits. These depositors are more likely to be
cautious and ready to move their money, because they know that they could lose
much of it if a bank goes under.

So when First Republic’s investment strategy began backfiring, depositors
started to pull out their money in large numbers — a classic bank run. By last
week, First Republic revealed that customers had withdrawn more than half of the
bank’s deposits.

Last, the three banks’ fates were connected. “The failure of Silicon Valley Bank
made Americans more concerned about the safety of their deposits,” my colleague
Maureen Farrell, who covers finance, said. “And First Republic looked a lot like
Silicon Valley Bank.” The threat of further contagion is what led regulators and
the financial system to move to try to stabilize the situation.

The problems largely come down to mismanagement at the three banks, experts
said. But regulators share some of the responsibility for failing to spot
warnings and to act on them earlier. The Federal Reserve acknowledged as much
last week
[https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/HkkDCeLzYvDz_QN5Y_A7BQ~~/AAAAAQA~_t5FBkAHB7MVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~],
saying that regulatory changes and a “shift in culture” left regulators
unprepared. The Fed also placed some of the blame on Congress, which in 2018
reduced the central bank’s oversight of so-called midsize banks like First
Republic and Silicon Valley Bank. The Fed is now considering tougher rules.


ECONOMIC FALLOUT

What happens next? Some analysts argue that the worst is over: Silicon Valley
Bank, Signature and First Republic were all outliers, and their similarities
made them unusually vulnerable to the current moment. So far, the government’s
swift responses seem to have done a good job containing the potential contagion.

But things could get worse. Economists say that the Federal Reserve’s interest
rate hikes take time — potentially more than a year — to work through the
economy. It was only last year that the Fed began dramatically raising rates.
The three banks’ collapses, then, could be the beginning. As higher interest
rates warp the economy, other parts of the financial system could fall under the
strain, too.

Regardless of which scenario plays out, the three bank failures could lead to an
economic slowdown. As other banks and investors worry that they could meet a
similar fate as First Republic, they may act more cautiously. That caution could
translate to less money going to businesses and consumers, meaning less economic
activity and growth overall.


MORE FINANCIAL COVERAGE

 * To prevent future bank runs, the F.D.I.C. proposed protecting larger deposits
   than it now does.
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/iZ3iRFowbiKGy3VirT6b0Q~~/AAAAAQA~_t5FBkAHB7MVIfZWVsYWFmemFoaWRAY29sbGVnZS5oYXJ2YXJkLmVkdVgEAAAAAA~~]
 * Executives at the major U.S. banks spent the weekend analyzing First
   Republic’s financials. Here’s how JPMorgan came out on top
   [https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/yP0RTPatNLhg9JkGZdUljw~~/AAAAAQA~/RgRmM2ntP0TiaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wNS8wMS9idXNpbmVzcy9maXJzdC1yZXB1YmxpYy1qcG1vcmdhbi1mZGljLmh0bWw_Y2FtcGFpZ25faWQ9OSZlbWM9ZWRpdF9ubl8yMDIzMDUwMiZpbnN0YW5jZV9pZD05MTU1NSZubD10aGUtbW9ybmluZyZyZWdpX2lkPTk4MTA5MTY4JnNlZ21lbnRfaWQ9MTMxODc4JnRlPTEmdXNlcl9pZD1iYTJmZjY5ZWQ2ZTlmZWM2ZjMxZjMyMmNlNTM0YmQxNVcDbnl0QgpkP-3kUGQAcHsxUh9lZWxhYWZ6YWhpZEBjb2xsZWdlLmhhcnZhcmQuZWR1WAQAAAAA].

Continue reading the main story

subject: [hcs-d] [HCS] [SHPE] CS Research Assistant Opportunity
text:
Hi all,

I am forwarding this message for Professor Davies-Escobar at the Graduate
School of Education (HGSE). You can contact him at
*emmerich_davies_escobar@gse.harvard.edu
<emmerich_davies_escobar@gse.harvard.edu>* if you are interested! Below is
the opportunity he sent over.

Best,
Sophi Salamanca
_____________
"We are looking for someone to assist us in building a corpus suitable for
Natural Language Processing from thousands of pages of textbooks. Because
textbooks have irregular formatting, we need someone to first develop an
approach that learns the format of a textbook page, and then extracts the
text from the textbook page in a reasonable format. For example, in the
following textbook page, we would need to record the page number, the
chapter title (“Medieval India”), the section header (“Shah Jahan”) and the
picture caption. We also need the text to be saved accurately, which
requires identifying that there are two columns of text, and the page reads
from left to right by column.

We recommend starting with Melissa Dell’s layoutparser package, and seeing
if it can perform well on our textbook corpus."

The Augmentation Residency is a 10-week-long residential program where 6-10

creative storytelling to produce innovations backed by rigorous research,

augmentation technologies to extend human capabilities & improve the human
condition. From eye gaze controlled supernumerary robotic limbs

subject: Inside SEAS: Design Fair, Awards, and more
text:
May 1, 2023


** April 24, 2023
------------------------------------------------------------


** IN THIS ISSUE
------------------------------------------------------------
* News & Announcements (#news)
* SEAS Community Events (#communityevents)
* Harvard Events (#harvardevents)


** News & Announcements
------------------------------------------------------------


** SEC Late Night Café free food
------------------------------------------------------------
Once a week from 7-9:15 p.m., the SEC Café offers a free item as part of their evening service. The free item for Wednesday, April 26 is:
* Brownie Sundae


** REEF Makerspace Innovation Fund for faculty and staff
------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to generous support provided by SEAS Community Connections Fund, The REEF Makerspace in the SEC is excited to announce they are now accepting applications from SEAS staff and faculty to create and make personal projects to be worked on over the summer.

They are looking for innovative and creative proposals that showcase skills and passions. Once approved, the REEF staff will be able to meet with individuals accepted into the program to discuss project designs and provide feedback.

To help bring your project to life, the REEF is offering funding up to $300. In addition to financial support, accepted proposals will receive assistance from experienced staff in areas such as material purchasing, machinery, software training, and engineering support. They are committed to ensuring that your project is a success and will work closely with you throughout the process.
Don’t miss this opportunity to turn your ideas into reality with the support of the REEF. Submit your proposal (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeqkZHAACwBfjwdNGC9i9iBADX8r5P4Rk8_lGsuGUK4oSpivA/viewform?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) and take your first step towards bringing your vision to life. The deadline to apply is Friday, May 5. Community members will hear back by mid-May on accepted projects.


** Call for applications: New World Social Innovation Fellows
------------------------------------------------------------
The New World Social Innovation Fellows Program (https://sici.hks.harvard.edu/homepage/new-world-social-innovation-fellowship/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)  is a rigorous co-curricular program for change-makers committed to addressing critical social problems in new and creative ways. The Fellows Program supports selected students – known as Cheng Fellows – advancing progress on a social problem through an effort of their own design. Through weekly co-curricular programming, coaching, mentoring, and seed funding, the Fellowship provides a platform for students to explore, develop, and scale efforts while in school and post-graduation. Collectively, Fellows’ work represents innovation across issues, around the world, and within sectors - encompassing civil society, business, government, and NGO organizations.

Applicants from SEAS master’s programs must graduate in Spring 2024. Doctoral students may apply as rising second-year students or rising third-year students (Spring 2026 or 2027 graduation). The application for this program opens Friday, May 5, and closes Monday, June 5.


** SEAS Community Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 25, May 17: Bike events
------------------------------------------------------------
Harvard CommuterChoice is hosting a couple bike-themed events (including one at the SEC) this semester.

Bike Maintenance Basics Workshop
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Bring your bikes and bike parts to work 1:1 with a bike mechanic
* Register your bike or micromobility device

Date: Tuesday, April 25
Time: 1:30 - 3:30 p.m.
Location: SEC Makerspace, 150 Western Ave., Allston

Annual Bike Breakfast
* 10-minute tune-ups and bike safety checks
* Register your bike or micromobility device
* Enter to win bike prizes
* Breakfast catered by Oggi's

Date: Wednesday, May 17
Time: 8 - 10 a.m.
Location: Smith Campus Center patio, 75 Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge


** May 22 - 25: Commencement Affinity Celebrations (https://edib.harvard.edu/affinity-graduations?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Affinity celebrations are student-led, staff supported events that recognize and celebrate the accomplishments of graduates from marginalized and underrepresented communities. These University-wide celebrations provide an opportunity for graduates to honor those who have helped them achieve their milestone while centering their cultural traditions and values. Affinity celebrations are open to all Harvard graduates who pre-register to attend. The celebrations include keynote speakers, performances and cultural celebrations.

Registration for the 2023 Affinity Celebrations will close on Monday, April 24. If you have questions, please contact edib@harvard.edu (mailto:edib@harvard.edu) .


** [See all SEAS events] (https://events.seas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------


** Harvard Events
------------------------------------------------------------


** April 27: HMSC 10-Year Anniversary (https://hmsc.harvard.edu/calendar_event/anniversary-celebration/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
Celebrate the 10-Year Anniversary of the Harvard Museums of Science & Culture (HMSC) by visiting one or all four HMSC museums to collect museum swag, enjoy birthday cupcakes, participate in raffles, or explore galleries. HMSC is free for Harvard ID holders.



** April 27-30: ARTS FIRST (https://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/arts-first-2023-events?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
ARTS FIRST is Harvard's annual showcase of student, faculty, and Harvard affiliate creativity. Produced by the Office for the Arts, with support from the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, the festival is a public event with many free performances and activities for Harvard and community members of all ages.



** May 8: Creating the Climate Future: Harvard Climate Leadership Summit (https://www.harvardcls.com/index.php?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
All Harvard students are invited to attend the inaugural Harvard Climate Leadership Summit during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). The summit will provide a platform that convenes students and decision-makers across industry, government and civil society to cultivate a rising generation of climate leadership. There will be an opportunity to meet the Emerging Climate Leaders, a passionate and diverse group of students who are dedicated to tackling climate change. They are the next generation of leaders committed to building a more sustainable and equitable future.



** May 9: Harvard Climate Symposium (https://harvardclimatesymposium.cventevents.com/event/c2f2acd5-bd80-49de-b1d3-4206bc0c7c76/summary?rp=b485e4a4-efad-42bf-9efc-e57a893288f1&utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381)
------------------------------------------------------------
The Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability is hosting a Climate Symposium during Harvard Climate Action Week (May 8 - 12). This new Institute serves as a fulcrum for collaboration across Harvard’s many areas of expertise, pursuing practical, real-world solutions that address all aspects of the climate crisis.

The Symposium represents the first major event of the Salata Institute’s Climate Action Accelerator (https://salatainstitute.harvard.edu/the-accelerator/?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) . The Accelerator will serve as a resource and partner to the full spectrum of stakeholders wrestling with the most difficult and divisive climate questions, building consensus for climate solutions grounded in Harvard’s research and expertise.


** SEAS suggestion box
------------------------------------------------------------
SEAS welcomes your ideas for ways to improve the school, build community, and make things work more efficiently. Submit feedback, suggestions, or ideas (https://harvard.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ah3D4tyjx30av5z?utm_source=SEAS+Community&utm_campaign=5d5defddaa-InsideSEAS_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_4c60eab88d-5d5defddaa-430354381) . Include your name if you wish; otherwise all submissions are anonymous.


** Submit your news to Inside SEAS
------------------------------------------------------------
Inside SEAS is published weekly. If you would like to have news featured in future editions, please email Matt Goisman (mailto:mgoisman@g.harvard.edu?subject=Inside%20SEAS%20Submission) by 5 p.m. on Thursdays. Inside SEAS can help you share news and announcements with a wider audience.

While we make every effort to publish all items received, the editorial staff reserves the right to reject submissions and edit content for space and style.

**
Ruth's Corner
------------------------------------------------------------
It appears that 2023 is a difficult year to find a summer internship in Europe. There are still internships to be had at this date, but you need to make sure that the internship salary or stipend will cover your costs (i.e., don't expect Harvard or outside subsidies). I continue to list some on Crimson Careers. A few suggestions:

Have a great cover letter.
Sign up for the company's newsletter.  Read their published reports/newsletter to gain more insight into the company and find a contact at the company that way.  This information could provide a great starting sentence for your cover letter.

Use key words or phrasing that the company uses.
If a company such Altman Solon (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=88187a707a&e=65d2b2b7c0) (which has three internships listed: Strategy Intern in Milan/Italy, (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=a242d79308&e=65d2b2b7c0) Research intern, (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=e0d5260bab&e=65d2b2b7c0) and Strategy Intern Munich) (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=745905f01b&e=65d2b2b7c0) is talking about "Consultants" ,"Services" and "Expertise," then you should use these terms in your cover letter and maybe even in your resume.

Expand your internship search beyond a certain geographical area.
Many European companies have international subsidiaries. If your goal was to be in Europe this summer, you might still find an internship with the same company, but in a different location. A good example would be Zeiss (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=93da6237b9&e=65d2b2b7c0) , which offers internships worldwide.

Use different search terms and consider industries that you have not considered before.
Here are a few companies that offer internships:
Rocket Factory Augsburg (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=8eaadd9afd&e=65d2b2b7c0)  - international space start-up company.
SAP (https://harvard.us1.list-manage.com/track/click?u=598d73b470a40f403bba4fb2c&id=45cbbc761e&e=65d2b2b7c0)

Companies are not always offering internships online, and deadlines are sometimes missing in the descriptions of those that are.  Find companies that are of interest to you and apply - even if there are no internships advertised.

subject: "In the House With No Doors" by Sarah Kay
text:
we have given up on knocking.

https://www.facebook.com/POETSorg/?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://twitter.com/POETSorg?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID

https://www.instagram.com/poetsorg/?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID


Support Poem-a-Day (http://poets.org/donate/pad?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
https://poets.org/poem-a-day?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID
May 2, 2023


**
------------------------------------------------------------


** In the House With No Doors (http://poets.org/poem/house-no-doors?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID)
------------------------------------------------------------
Sarah Kay (https://poets.org/poet/sarah-kay?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID)

we have given up on knocking.
Incoming! we say, with our eyes lowered for modesty,
or, Hello! or sometimes, Sorry, sorry!
You have to pass through everyone’s bedroom
to get to the kitchen. We only have two bathrooms.
As a courtesy, nobody will poop while you are showering,
but they might have to do their makeup or shave
if they are in a rush, if we have somewhere to be,
so you can recognize every person by their whistle
through a wet shower curtain, you haven’t seen your own face
on an unfogged mirror in weeks. It doesn’t matter,
self-consciousness has no currency here.
If you were nosy, I suppose the little bathroom trashcans
would spill their secrets to you, but why bother,
privacy is a language we don’t speak.
Someone is always awake before you,
the smell of coffee easing you into a today
they have already entered,
a bridge you will never need to cross first,
and no matter how latenight your owl,
there is always someone still awake
to eat popcorn with, to whisper your daily report to,
to compare notes on what good news you each caught in your nets.
In bed, you say, Goodnight! in one direction
and someone says it back, then turns and passes it,
so you fall asleep to the echo of goodnights down the long hallway
’til it donuts its way back around to your pillow.
Someone is doing a load of laundry,
if anyone wants to add some extra socks?
Someone is clearing the dishes,
someone has started singing Gershwin in the backyard
and you can’t help but harmonize,
and for a moment what you always hoped was true
finally is: loneliness has forgotten your address,
french toast browning on the stovetop,
the sound of everyone you love
clear as the sun giggling through the window,
not even a doorknob between you.

Copyright © 2023 by Sarah Kay. Originally published in Poem-a-Day on May 2, 2023, by the Academy of American Poets.
https://traffic.megaphone.fm/POETS5539757401.mp3?updated=1682705289&mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID


** Subscribe to the Poem-a-Day Podcast
------------------------------------------------------------
https://podcasts.apple.com/podcast/id1497937744?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://open.spotify.com/show/7rEVm3YLMej7WWvhaIAJya?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID https://podcasts.google.com/?feed=aHR0cHM6Ly9mZWVkcy5tZWdhcGhvbmUuZm0vcG9lbS1hLWRheQ%3D%3D&mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID

“I have an annual tradition which involves a large group of friends gathering together in a small house for a weekend. We are too old and there are too many of us to justify the way we cram into this tiny house—filling every corner, sleeping on couches and floors, and staying up too late, but it is a giddy, joyful weekend that refills my heart’s fuel tank for the whole year. This poem came out of imagining a world in which this was not a rare brief treat, but a state of togetherness I could inhabit.”
—Sarah Kay
https://poets.org/poet/sarah-kay?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID

Sarah Kay (https://poets.org/poet/sarah-kay?mc_cid=92a4b7ef6b&mc_eid=UNIQID) is the author of All Our Wild Wonder (Hachette, 2018) and The Type (Hachette, 2016), among other titles. The co-director of Project Voice, she is originally from New York City.

subject: 📣 US workers get loud
text:
…and Argentina leans on the USD as it faces triple-digit inflation
 

The union train gains steam (Jason Redmond/Getty Images)

 
Yesterday’s Market Moves
 
Dow Jones
34,052 (-0.14%)		S&P 500

Nasdaq

Hey Snackers,

The only thing worse than forgetting your keys in a cab: forgetting your poodle. Uber's annual lost-and-found index includes everything from a unicycle to a single Gucci loafer to a bidet.

Stocks ticked down yesterday after the troubled First Republic Bank was offloaded to JPMorgan Chase in the second-largest bank failure in US history. Meanwhile, earnings season is marching on: over half of S&P 500 companies have reported, and 80% beat estimates.

Organized

While union membership is at a record low, US labor movements are gaining steam

May Day was yesterday… but worker momentum is just heating up. US labor unions have been making headlines as looming deadlines could lead to a power shift. Most pressing: the 11.5K film and TV writers represented by the Writers Guild of America are set to strike against studios today, barring an 11th-hour agreement. It’s not just your fave shows that could come to a halt: workers in other key industries are engaged in tense negotiations.

  • Taking off: yesterday 15K American Airlines pilots voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike, though federal laws make it harder for airline unions to join walkouts.

  • Gearing up: UPS and 340K unionized delivery workers have kicked off contract negotiations for their July 31 deadline. Contracted Amazon drivers in California unionized last month, gaining a $30/hour wage.

  • Foaming: About 300 US Starbucks stores have voted to unionize so far. Last week, federal labor prosecutors alleged that the latte leader refused to negotiate fairly at 144 locations.

Big stories, low numbers… Despite splashy organizing efforts, US union membership was just 10% last year, the lowest rate on record. Still, Americans’ support of unions is nearly at a 60-year high, with over half seeing the decline of organized labor as negative. Meanwhile, with historically low unemployment and still-high inflation, workers’ wage expectations are rising, reaching $76K/year in March.

THE TAKEAWAY

The power dynamic’s in flux… While the pandemic saw the employee/employer dynamic tilt in favor of workers in areas like remote work and wage hikes, layoffs and RTO plans have shifted power back toward the boardroom. But even in defeat, labor movements can bring about change: public criticism of a blocked nationwide rail strike in December led major rail companies to grant workers paid sick leave.

Greenback

Argentina leans on the US dollar as the value of its national currency tanks

Inflation nation… As Argentina’s economic crisis deepens, its citizens are relying on the dolar blue, aka the US dollar. Inflation breached 100% last month for the first time in decades as prices doubled. To combat that, Argentina’s central bank jacked its interest rate by 10 percentage points, to 91%, last Thursday — tacking on to a massive 300-point lift the week before.

  • For context: The Fed has cranked the US’s rate to about 5% from zilch over the past year, in response to inflation that hit 9%.

  • Not enough: For Argentina, 20 to 30% inflation is typical, but triple digits means time to hit the panic button. However, aggressive rate hikes, along with price freezes and other scattershot attempts to cool prices, aren’t working.

Dollarization nation… Argentines trust the greenback to maintain its value more than the peso. The USD has become so prevalent in the country that some experts think its circulation there is second only to the US. Argentines trade pesos for American dollars at illegal swap hubs, where the exchange rate is often cranked to double the official rate.

  • Paging Washington: One of Argentina’s presidential candidates, Javier Milei, wants to fully swap the national currency out for the USD and dissolve the country’s central bank. FYI: 11 countries, including Ecuador and Zimbabwe, use the USD as their currency.
THE TAKEAWAY

The buck still has Superman status… Concerns about the US dollar being dethroned as the world’s “Superman Currency” may be overblown. Despite its value slipping this year, the USD is still relied on as the world’s go-to currency for international purchases (think: oil trades), accounting for 58% of global forex reserves. Meanwhile, other countries’ preference for the dollar can make their own currencies weaker.

DEFI(NE)

Heard on the Block: "crypto whale"

🐋 When you're so big even your tiniest move makes a splash…

A "crypto whale" is a person or entity that holds so much cryptocurrency that they have the power to affect its price. Picture: selling large amounts of a token at once. Binance-owned CoinMarketCap said it'll launch a reality-TV show, "Killer Whales," which will feature entrepreneurs pitching web3 biz ideas to a panel of whales and investors. Picture: “Shark Tank” for crypto.

What else we're Snackin'

  • JPMore: JPMorgan Chase took over First Republic Bank after the midsize lender became the third to fail since March. Jamie Dimon, the CEO of America’s largest bank, said "this part" of the banking crisis is over.

  • Sparkle: Prebiotic soda maker Olipop said it expects to double its sales this year to $200M and that Coke and Pepsi have approached it. The healthier-bev market's thriving as Americans increasingly ditch soda.

  • AIGuy: Geoffrey Hinton, a pioneer known as the "godfather of AI," quit his Google job and warned that the tech could have "scary" repercussions. AI regulation is emerging as companies race to incorporate bots.

  • Lawshoe: Adidas shareholders sued the shoemaker over its imploded partnership with Kanye West following the rapper’s antisemitic comments. Adidas lost $633M in Q4 after the un-Yeezy split.

  • BAInance: Binance said its CEO is the target of an AI-powered smear campaign that had ChatGPT claim he worked with a Chinese state oil company. Experts caution that AI could be used to spread misinfo.

🍪 Thanks for Snacking with us! Want to share the Snacks? Invite your friends to sign up here.

Snack Fact Of the Day
“The Super Mario Bros. Movie” is the first film of the year to top $1B+ in sales

subject: Support and Wellbeing During Reading Period and Finals
text:
http://dso.college.harvard.edu


** Support and Wellbeing During Reading Period and Finals
------------------------------------------------------------
SUPPORT RESOURCES → (https://dso.college.harvard.edu/getting-support)

Dear
Eelaaf,
As you navigate final exams and projects, I wanted to remind you of the resources and support available to you. During this busy time, it is important to take care of yourself – be sure to prioritize your wellbeing. Simple steps like getting enough sleep, eating regular meals, drinking plenty of water, and asking for help if you need it can have a big impact. In addition, please take a moment to review the resources below and access them if you need support. 


** Urgent Support
------------------------------------------------------------
CAMHS CARES
Th e CAMHS Cares Line (https://camhs.huhs.harvard.edu/camhs-cares)  (617-495-2042) is a 24/7 support line for Harvard students who have mental health concerns, whether you are in immediate distress or not, on-campus or elsewhere.
TIMELY CARE
Students who have paid for the Student Health Fee are eligible to access TimelyCare (https://camhs.huhs.harvard.edu/timelycare) . As part of Harvard’s partnership with TimelyMD, students have access to services in TimelyCare, including scheduled counseling, psychiatry, self-care content, a peer support community, and unlimited health coaching.

Students who graduate in May will have access to TimelyCare until July 31 (when your Student Health Fee expires). Eligibility renews when you register for the next academic year.


** Wellbeing and Mental Health
------------------------------------------------------------
COUNSELING AND MENTAL HEALTH (CAMHS) RESOURCES
CAMHS offers a wide variety of resources to help navigate anxiety and stressful situations (https://camhs.huhs.harvard.edu/camhs-resources) . Their Managing Emotions (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/managing_emotions_and_stress_2022-2023)  series provides stress management and emotion regulation skills to help you cultivate greater calm and resilience.
HARVARD CHAPLAINS
The Harvard Chaplains (https://chaplains.harvard.edu/) , a professional community of more than thirty chaplains, represent many of the world’s religious, spiritual, and ethical traditions, and share a collective commitment to serving the spiritual needs of the students, faculty, postdoctoral researchers, and staff of Harvard University.
PEER COUNSELING
Room 13 (https://camhs.huhs.harvard.edu/links/room-13) is a confidential, non-judgmental, non-directive peer counseling service for Harvard undergraduates. Room 13 aims to provide a safe space for you to talk about anything on your mind. They counsel on gender, identity, SES, alcohol and drugs, grief, relationships, eating, health, school, and anything else you may need help with.
WE'RE ALL HUMAN CAMPAIGN
Intellectual growth and academic achievement should not come at the expense of wellbeing. Discover wellbeing and mental health resources (https://www.harvard.edu/wellbeing/wellness-resources/) available to you.


** Academic Support
------------------------------------------------------------
Support is available if you’re facing academic difficulties or special circumstances such as illness. Course instructors and members of your advising network are all here to help you. Learn about academic support resources (https://dso.college.harvard.edu/academic-support)  and check out the Harvard College Guide to Reading and Examination Period (https://college.harvard.edu/guides/reading-and-examination-period) .

If you are looking for additional resources, please see the Dean of Students Office Getting Support (https://dso.college.harvard.edu/getting-support) web page.

Wishing you the best of luck with the end of the semester and a wonderful summer,
Lauren Brandt
Interim Dean of Students

subject: Final Exams: Important Reminders
text:
https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=announcement&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=home&utm_content=preheader


** alarm clock icon REMINDER
------------------------------------------------------------


** Prepare for Spring Final Exams
------------------------------------------------------------


** — Review dates, locations, and policies.
------------------------------------------------------------
Before you take your exams, be aware of the guidelines about academic integrity and what to do if something goes wrong, such as if you get sick on the day of your exam.
Re-read the Honor Code (https://honor.fas.harvard.edu/honor-code)
Dear Eelaaf,

As you prepare for final assignments, I write to remind you about the policies and procedures associated with the Final Examination period, beginning on Thursday, May 4.

Exam period can be busy and stressful, but remember that you always have resources and advisers who can help – please don’t hesitate to reach out for support.
SUPPORT THROUGHOUT EXAMS
------------------------------------------------------------
* Have an adviser, family member, tutor/proctor, faculty member or staff member in mind whom you can call when things get toughest.
* Ask for help and communicate with faculty and advisers as soon as possible when issues come up.
* If in doubt, reach out to your Resident Dean (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us12.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3Deb85d7a5a3fb4e531ad907e64-26id-3Db2b1fe857e-26e-3D642f08eb39&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=292nPpjY6u22mNjeAgkR--fqyX7gjCElISgq0YBNVBQ&m=hzyfktdshFif9XYYYH1AurtxLb5ZQ7PZMb_XPaF_Gs4&s=sbChMJOIMdGRuMre7FWKvPUkVi-9rPMbAoGH297Ae60&e=)  or First-Year Resident Dean (https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__harvard.us12.list-2Dmanage.com_track_click-3Fu-3Deb85d7a5a3fb4e531ad907e64-26id-3D47ea689440-26e-3D642f08eb39&d=DwMFaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=292nPpjY6u22mNjeAgkR--fqyX7gjCElISgq0YBNVBQ&m=hzyfktdshFif9XYYYH1AurtxLb5ZQ7PZMb_XPaF_Gs4&s=2aRl1WydwxZqbNPyjxJM83681tFImwvk1k_grEgGsB8&e=)  between now and the end of the semester. They can help you figure out your options and solve problems.

Please take some time to fully review the policies and tips included below – the following information may save you time and reduce stress during the exam period.

Wishing you a successful end of term,

Christina Pasquale
Associate Registrar of Academic Planning, Faculty of Arts and Sciences Registrar's Office, Harvard University

Qussay Al-Attabi
Assistant Dean for Academic Integrity and Student Conduct and Secretary of the Honor Council, Harvard University


**  EXAM HELP AND TIPS
------------------------------------------------------------


** Before an Exam
------------------------------------------------------------
REVIEW POLICIES
------------------------------------------------------------
Understand 2022-23 extensions of time policy (https://handbook.college.harvard.edu/files/collegehandbook/files/harvard_college_student_handbook2223.pdf)
If you encounter unexpected difficulties in completing your work, you should consult your Resident Dean. Extensions of time up to the end of the Examination Period may be granted by your instructor, but extensions beyond the Examination Period can only be granted by vote of the Administrative Board.

Re-read the Honor Code (https://honor.fas.harvard.edu/honor-code) .
Review the course policies and check with your instructor if you are uncertain about any exam rules.

Review the Examination Rules (https://handbook.college.harvard.edu/files/collegehandbook/files/harvardcollege_studenthandbook_2021_2022.pdf#page=42) .
Know what is permitted during your exam.

CHECK DATES
------------------------------------------------------------
Review your final exam dates and locations (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/take-exams#exam-schedule) .
Do not miss the scheduled time of your exam. Know the dates and locations (they will probably be different from where you have class) and add them to your calendar or planner.

Re-read the syllabus for each of your courses.
Know the deadlines for any final assignments and understand the collaboration policy for the course.

Check the time and location for your out of sequence exam if you have one.
If you are scheduled for an out of sequence exam, please note the time and location may be different from the main exam. Please review your exam details in the emails from exams@fas.harvard.edu (mailto:exams@fas.harvard.edu?subject=Final%20Exam%20Schedule) .


** 24 Hours Before an Exam
------------------------------------------------------------
KNOW WHAT TO DO IF YOU GET SICK
------------------------------------------------------------
If you are sick during the 24 hours before your exam, call HUHS Urgent Care (https://huhs.harvard.edu/urgent-care) .
Explain that you are unwell and scheduled to take an exam within the next 24 hours. If you are instructed to go to HUHS Urgent Care, make sure to  request a medical make-up form. Let your Resident Dean know you will miss your exam and give them the make-up form so they can help you with the make-up exam process.

PREPARE TO WAKE UP ON TIME
------------------------------------------------------------
Create a back-up plan to wake up.
Set a second alarm (or a few!). Ask someone to call or check on you to make sure that you are awake. If you oversleep, contact your Resident Dean immediately.

Get plenty of sleep.
Do not try to stay up all night and risk sleeping through your exam.

Double check your exam time/location.
Make sure you know where you are going.


** During an Exam
------------------------------------------------------------
KNOW WHAT TO DO IF YOU GET SICK
------------------------------------------------------------
If you are sick during your exam, immediately let your instructor know.
You are required to call HUHS Urgent Care (https://huhs.harvard.edu/urgent-care)  (617-495-5711) to let them know you are leaving your exam due to illness.
* If you are too sick to go to HUHS on your own, your instructor will contact someone from HUPD to accompany you.
* Once you arrive at Urgent Care, you are not permitted to communicate with anyone except your health care providers until you are able to resume your exam, and you will be directed to contact your Resident Dean about your illness.
* When you resume your exam, you will only be allowed the balance of time remaining to finish it.

FOLLOW EXAM POLICIES
------------------------------------------------------------
Arrive on time!
You may not be allowed to take an exam if you arrive late, and you will definitely not be allowed to take the exam if you arrive after the first student has left the room. 

Follow the Honor Code.
Cheating on exams or problem sets, plagiarizing or misrepresenting the ideas or language of someone else as one’s own, falsifying data, or any other instance of academic dishonesty violates the standards of our community.

Sit through the exam, even if it is not worth a large part of your grade.
If a course has a final exam, then you are required to take it  in order to pass the course (or arrange for a make-up exam).
MAKEUP EXAM DATES
If you miss your seated final exam, and you are approved for a makeup exam through the Administrative Board, please be aware of the makeup exam dates. As a reminder, these dates were carefully determined in order to allow students to start their semester free of prior academic commitments, as well as minimizing the time between the main exam and the makeup exam.
Makeup Exam Dates:
* Fall 2023: Exams from Spring 2023
+ Dates: Tuesday, August 29 and Wednesday, August 30, 2023

The Administrative Board has jurisdiction over granting makeup examinations. The Registrar's Office will notify students approved to take makeup exam(s) via email. The email notification will specify the scheduled time and place of the makeup examination(s). The Registrar's Office will continue to administer makeup exams at the Student Organization Center at Hilles unless otherwise communicated.


** calendar icon KEY DATES AND DEADLINES
------------------------------------------------------------
MAY
04

Final examination period begins (https://calendar.college.harvard.edu/event/final_examination_period_703?utm_campaign=widget&utm_medium=widget&utm_source=Harvard+College+Calendar)
Final examination period runs through May 13, 2023.
View the 2022-23 Harvard College Academic Calendar (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/calendars#upcoming) .


** RESOURCES
------------------------------------------------------------
Academic Resource Center (ARC) (https://academicresourcecenter.harvard.edu/college-students)
The ARC has a variety of resources to support you during finals.
Final exam schedule (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/take-exams#exam-schedule)
The three hour final exam schedule includes times of exams and the locations.

Harvard College Student Handbook (https://handbook.college.harvard.edu/)
Review the academic requirements of the College as well as the Honor Code and standards of our community.
Harvard College Guide to Reading and Exam Period (https://college.harvard.edu/guides/reading-and-examination-period)
View tips and tricks for navigating the exam period, answers to frequently asked questions, and more.

============================================================
** Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences Registrar's Office (https://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/?utm_source=announcement&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=home&utm_content=footer)

subject: [hcs-d] Science, Technology & Society Fellowship application due 5/13
text:
Ever wanted to better understand opposition to vaccines? Misinformation in
a “post-truth” world? How efforts to address climate change emerge at the
global level in relation to local interests? The place of science and
technology (S&T) in a world increasingly defined by various kinds of
“risk”? Relationships between public institutions and private companies
when it comes to innovation and governance?


If you’re interested in any of these questions — or, more broadly,
intersections of and relationships between science, technology, society,
politics, and policy — join the *Harvard Kennedy School **Program on
Science, Technology and Societ <http://sts.hks.harvard.edu/>y
<http://sts.hks.harvard.edu/>**’s <http://sts.hks.harvard.edu> (STS)
Undergraduate Fellowship for the fall semester!* Learn more and *apply here
by May 13 <http://tinyurl.com/undergradfellowsf23>*.


[image: UF_f23_flyer.png]


Thanks,

Aishani

subject: [ADAMS] Looking for a job?
text:
Hi everyone,

I wanted to reach out with a full-time job opportunity for anyone
interested in working in a biology lab! This position is especially great
for any graduating seniors looking for some more lab experience before
going on to graduate school/medical school. The Buratowski lab, which is in
the BCMP department at Harvard Medical School, is looking for a lab
technician/research assistant, with a possibility to start as early as this
month. The application details as well as more information about the
position are in the document I have attached to this email.

I have been conducting research in the Buratowski lab since last summer and
cannot say enough about how great of a lab it is. We are pretty small,
which makes it a really close-knit environment where everyone is very
collaborative. Steve, the PI, is extremely accessible, and you would get to
be very involved in the research. Additionally, depending on how long you
plan to stay, Steve is very open to techs overseeing projects of their own.
Happy to answer any questions, as is Steve, about the lab environment or
the position itself!

Best,
Brynn

_______________________________________________
